_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Administrative controls (Operating procedures, speed limit, etc.) in place and in-line excess flow automatic shutdown valves.
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Routine Visual inspections by the trained operators
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Update inspection procedure after receiving ammonia or reacting.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: NH3 tanks, piping, hoses and related equipment

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
WinField United - Hastings, NE

We are committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by continually improving both practices and measures to prevent the release of regulated substances.  In the event of a release, the Hastings facility is prepared to work with the Adams County LEPC and/or other authorities to mitigate any release and minimize the impact to people and the environment.

The Hastings facility's primary covered process activity is the storage of anhydrous ammonia.  The anhydrous ammonia is used by a third-party company called Blick's Phosphate Conversions, LLC to manufacture liquid fertilizer in a reaction process.  Anhydrous ammonia is received and processed into 10-34-0 non-hazardous liquid fertilizer.  Processing is periodic and usually occurs in the Spring and Fall.  Ammonia mixing with phosphoric acid occurs in a T-reactor owned and operated by Blick's Phosphate Conversions, LLC.  Water is used as both a reaction feed material and product stabilizer.  The emergency procedures for the Hastings facility are coordinated with the Adams County LEPC.

WinField United - Hastings, NE  have taken the necessary steps to comply with accidental release prevention requirements set forth in 40 CFR Part 68.  The only process that this RMP includes is the storage of anhydrous ammonia. The T-reactor process is done entirely by Blick's Phosphate Conversions, LLC; and their process is also covered by OSHA's Process Safety Management standard. The following briefly describes the prevention program elements in place at this location for the storage of anhydrous ammonia:

Process Safety Information: The facility maintains information describing the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with the covered process.

Process Hazard Analysis: Studies are conducted to ensure the hazards associated with process operations are identified, understood and controlled.

Operating Procedures: The

facility has written operating procedures which are maintained for covered process operations and includes: initial startup, normal, temporary, emergency shutdown, normal shutdown and startup for the storage of Anhydrous Ammonia.

Hot Work Permits: In order to assure adequate controls are in place when ignition from flammable or combustible materials, the Hot Work Permit System is utilized.  Hot work involves any welding, soldering, cutting, grinding, drilling, or any type of work where sparks may occur during operation.  These permits will be utilized where hot work is necessary on the storage system.

Training: A program is in place to ensure employees of WinField United are knowledgeable and trained in procedures associated with the covered processes. 

Mechanical Integrity: The covered process equipment is maintained consistent with generally accepted engineering practices.  Covered process equipment is routinely inspected and tested.  Maintenance activities are conducted by qualified personnel. Deficiencies are corrected in a timely manner.

Management of Change: Written procedures are in place to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and/or procedures.  Affected personnel are informed and trained to deal with authorized system changes.

Pre-Startup Review: Technical and operational reviews will be conducted on new processes and/or modifications to existing covered processes.  Reviews confirm that the construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable. Reviews are completed prior to placing equipment in operation.

Compliance Audits: WinField United conducts internal audits based on each company's responsibly of working with Anhydrous Ammonia on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions specified under the RMP rule are being implemented.  At a minimum, these audits are conducted every three (3) years. Any determined corrective actions are completed in a timely manner.

Incident Investigations

: If an Incident were to occur, investigations would be conducted to determine the cause of covered process incidents.  In addition to determination and correction, investigations are directed toward preventing a reoccurrence. Investigations become process safety information and are retained for five (5) years.  

Employee Participation: WinField United employee(s) are contributing in the following: process hazard assessments, operating procedure development, maintenance procedure development, training development and implementation, pre-startup reviews, incident investigations, and compliance audits, based on each company's employee(s) responsibility of working with Anhydrous Ammonia.  Additionally, employee(s) have access to all information pertaining to the facility's RMP.

Contractors: Blick's Phosphate Conversions, LLC is hired to manufacture liquid fertilizer utilizing the anhydrous ammonia.  The are evaluated by ISN which is a third-party contractor evaluation service using criteria established by the facility.

Five (5) Year Accident History: There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five (5) years that have resulted in deaths, injuries or significant property damage. Nor to our knowledge, has there been any releases resulting in off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, property damage and/or environmental damage.

Emergency Action Plan: WinField United - Hastings, NE. Has a written emergency action plan.  This plan includes notification of the Adams County LEPC. Local authorities have been provided with emergency planning and community right-to-know information.  

Planned changes to improve safety: WinField United views safety improvement as a continual process.  Periodic evaluations (both internal and external) are performed to assess the facility status.  At this time, and aside from sustaining maintenance activities, there are no additional specific safety recommendations regarding the storage of anhydrous ammonia.
